org.grails.plugin.vaadin.ui
[Groovy] Class DefaultButtons

java.lang.Object
  com.vaadin.ui.AbstractComponent
      com.vaadin.ui.AbstractComponentContainer
          com.vaadin.ui.AbstractLayout
              com.vaadin.ui.AbstractOrderedLayout
                  com.vaadin.ui.HorizontalLayout
                      org.grails.plugin.vaadin.ui.DefaultButtons

class DefaultButtons
extends com.vaadin.ui.HorizontalLayout

A button toolbar that provides the ability to add the same buttons that are provided in standard Grails scaffolding, i.e.: 'create', 'update', 'delete', 'edit'

Note that users can subclass this class to add additional button types.

Authors:
Francis McKenzie

Property Detail

instance

java.lang.Object instance

 
Constructor Detail

DefaultButtons

DefaultButtons(java.lang.Object instance)
Create the toolbar with the specified domain instance. Note that the domain instance is used when creating the button links - e.g. the "id" of the domain instance is used.
Parameters:
instance - The instance of the domain class

 
Method Detail

addCreateButton

java.lang.Object addCreateButton(java.util.Map args)
Adds a 'create' button to the toolbar. This will link to the 'save' action of the current controller by default.
arg:
onClick Specify a closure that mimics the javascript 'onclick'. I.e. if it returns false, we don't action the link.
arg:
controller Change the controller that the button links to
arg:
action Change the action that the button links to
arg:
icon Change the icon Resource used for the button
Parameters:
args - A map of args for customising the button
Returns:
The added button

addDeleteButton

java.lang.Object addDeleteButton(java.util.Map args)
Adds a 'delete' button to the toolbar. This will link to the 'delete' action of the current controller by default. Note that by default this also triggers a modal popup window requesting the user to confirm, before deleting. If you don't want to use the popup window, specify [noConfirm:true] in the args.
arg:
noConfirm Prevent the modal confirmation popup window from being displayed
arg:
onClick Specify a closure that mimics the javascript 'onclick'. I.e. if it returns false, we don't action the link. Note this will only be called after the user has clicked OK on the modal popup window. If the popup window has been disabled with 'noConfirm', then this onClick closure is called immediately.
arg:
controller Change the controller that the button links to
arg:
action Change the action that the button links to
arg:
icon Change the icon Resource used for the button
Parameters:
args - A map of args for customising the button
Returns:
The added button

addEditButton

java.lang.Object addEditButton(java.util.Map args)
Adds a 'edit' button to the toolbar. This will link to the 'edit' action of the current controller by default.
arg:
onClick Specify a closure that mimics the javascript 'onclick'. I.e. if it returns false, we don't action the link.
arg:
controller Change the controller that the button links to
arg:
action Change the action that the button links to
arg:
icon Change the icon Resource used for the button
Parameters:
args - A map of args for customising the button
Returns:
The added button

addUpdateButton

java.lang.Object addUpdateButton(java.util.Map args)
Adds a 'update' button to the toolbar. This will link to the 'update' action of the current controller by default.
arg:
onClick Specify a closure that mimics the javascript 'onclick'. I.e. if it returns false, we don't action the link.
arg:
controller Change the controller that the button links to
arg:
action Change the action that the button links to
arg:
icon Change the icon Resource used for the button
Parameters:
args - A map of args for customising the button
Returns:
The added button

createConfirmPopup

protected java.lang.Object createConfirmPopup(java.lang.String prompt, groovy.lang.Closure onOK = null)
Creates a closure that can be used to open a popup window when a button is clicked.
arg:
prompt The prompt for the popup window
arg:
onOK The closure to run after the users clicks "OK"
